The Cu-based catalyst is a highly promising non-precious metal catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. Its activity and stability need to be improved. A specific ionic liquid, [Hnmpo]H2PO4, was developed to modulate the activated carbon-supported Cu (Cu/AC), and a supported ionic liquid-metal catalyst (Cu-[Hnmpo] H2PO4/AC) was prepared. With a n (Cu): n (N) molar ratio of 2:1, the catalyst achieved 89.16 % acetylene conversion and >99 % vinyl chloride selectivity under near-industrial conditions (150 °C, GHSV(C2H2)=50 h⁻¹, HCl/C2H2=1.0). Characterizations and theoretical calculations revealed that ionic liquids increased the stability and anti-carbon-deposition ability of Cu. Ionic liquids modulate the electronic properties of Cu through H2PO4 - anion. The active species in Cu (II) valence state were stably maintained, thereby promoting the activation of acetylene and HCl. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu-based catalyst Acetylene hydrochlorination Ionic liquid Catalytic upgrading Interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Plastic is an important raw material for modern industry[1]. Among them, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is one of the five commonly used engineering plastics in the world. PVC is now the third largest polymer by production volume. It finds widespread applications in diverse fields, including the construction industry, industry, national defense, medical, and consumer goods[2]. At present, PVC is mainly produced through the calcium carbide acetylene method. Hg catalyst is commonly used in this production process. However, Hg is highly toxic and environmentally damaging. Therefore, the research on developing green and non-toxic non-mercury catalysts is urgently needed. So far, numerous efficient catalysts have been developed, primarily based on precious metals such as Pd[3–5], Pt[6–8], Au[9–14], Ru[15–18]. However, their industrial application is severely limited by the high cost and poor long-term reaction stability. For sustainable development, non-precious metal catalysts represent the most promising alternatives to mercuric chloride systems. Their development has become a necessity. Among non-precious metal options, Cu-based catalysts exhibit excellent initial catalytic activity. Furthermore, they possess moderate standard electrode potential[19], low toxicity, good thermal stability, and low cost. Therefore, Cu-based catalysts are highly promising for acetylene hydrochlorination. There have been some studies on the application of Cu based catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination[20–26]. Modifications are necessary to enhance their activity and stability for potential industrial use. Current strategies to modulate metal catalysts for this reaction include several approaches. These are: adding the modifiers[27–30], modifying the support[31–36], introducing ligands[37–43], constructing bimetallic catalysts[44–46], and incorporating ionic liquids or deep eutectic solvent[47–51]. Among them, ionic liquids (ILs) are notable. They possess characteristics including low vapor pressure, high thermal stability, designability, and rich charges. Thus, they are widely used in catalysis. Ionic liquids can function directly as catalysts or serve as modifiers for metal catalysts. Furthermore, the supported ionic liquid is developed. The ionic liquid was immobilized on the surface of the carrier. The supported 47ionic liquids retain the excellent catalytic performance of the neat ILs. Additionally, they benefit from the high specific surface area provided by the support materials. The high specific surface can effectively reduce mass transfer limitations, improve reaction efficiency, and minimize the required amount of ionic liquid. The supported ionic liquid catalytic systems embody a catalytic model of “macroscopic heterogeneous catalysis, microscopic homogeneous catalysis”. This means they combine the advantages of homogeneous catalysis and heterogeneous catalysis. This model offers the good activity and high selectivity typical of homogeneous catalysis. Simultaneously, it provides the benefits of heterogeneous systems, namely the straightforward separation of products and easy catalyst recovery. Moreover, the coordination combination of anions and cations can be modulated to obtain specific physical and chemical properties. Therefore, supported ionic liquid-metal-based catalysts have found wide applications in multiphase catalysis. Examples include selective hydrogenation[52], coupling reactions[53,54], esterification reactions[55], and oxidation reactions[56]. However, in the field of acetylene hydrochlorination, supported ionic liquids are mainly used in Au-based catalysts[57–60] and Rh-based catalysts[15–18,61]. Their application on Cu-based catalysts is very limited[62,63]. Therefore, further research is needed to explore the modulation of Cu-based catalysts using supported ionic liquids. On the one hand, more types of supported ionic liquids effective for Cu-based catalysts should be developed. On the other hand, the micro-mechanisms responsible for catalytic performance enhancement require detailed investigation. Based on this, an ionic liquid ([Hnmpo] H2PO4) featuring pyrrole cations and H2PO4 anions was developed. This ionic liquid was used to modulate the activated carbon-supported Cu (Cu/AC). Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC was prepared using a simple impregnation method. Under reaction conditions approaching industrial levels, the catalyst demonstrated excellent performance. The catalyst achieved 89.16 % acetylene conversion. Additionally, it maintained vinyl chloride selectivity exceeding 99 %. The ionic liquid enhanced Cu stability and improved its resistance to carbon deposition. Furthermore, the H2PO4 - anion in the ionic liquid modulated Cu's electronic properties. This modulation increases the positive charge on Cu. Consequently, the catalytic system demonstrated enhanced activation of both acetylene and HCl. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Required amount of CuCl2 and ionic liquid ([Hnmpo]H2PO4) were weighed separately. CuCl2 was dissolved in deionized water. The ionic liquid was dissolved in deionized water or anhydrous ethanol, depending on its solubility. Then they were mixed and vigorously stirred for 1 hour. The resulting Cu-IL mixed solution underwent ultrasonic treatment for 30 min. Afterwards, the acid-washed activated carbon was slowly added to the solution. The mixture was stirred continuously to ensure full contact between the support and the solution. The support was allowed to impregnate at room temperature for 10 h. Subsequently, the sample was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h. The Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC catalyst was obtained. The catalyst with a % copper loading and a molar ratio of n (Cu): n (N)=b was labeled as aCu-IL/AC-b. The control catalyst, Cu/AC, was prepared following the same procedure but without adding the ionic liquid. The catalyst with 10 % copper loading was denoted as 10Cu/AC. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The low-temperature N2 physical adsorption-desorption test was conducted on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. Before nitrogen adsorption, a sample of 150–200 mg was degassed under vacuum conditions at 150 °C for 6 h. This degassing process removed on the surface impurities and adsorbed species (air, moisture) from the pores. Following degassing, nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C (liquid nitrogen temperature). Measurements were conducted over an absolute pressure range of 10⁻⁷ to 0.1 MPa. The XRD patterns were obtained by a PANalytic X'Pert Pro diffractometer. The instrument utilized Cu K α rays (λ=0.154 nm) and operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Data were over a 2θ range of 5–80°with a step size of 0.02°The SEM images were obtained by the Nova Nano SEM 450 device. The instrument was operated with an acceleration voltage of 30 kV. It was equipped with an X-ray energy spectrometer (EDS). This additional equipment allowed us to analyze the surface elemental distribution. TEM analysis was performed using a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Win. The instrument was operated at a voltage of 300 kV. This microscope was also equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyzer for elemental analysis and mapping. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) measurements were performed on the Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. The instrument was equipped with three key components: Omni intelligent full function sampling, Nicolet Continu accessories, and a diamond pressure cell. Spectra were collected in the range of 4000–400 cm⁻¹. The resolution was better than 0.09 cm-1. The signal-to-noise ratio exceeded 50,000:1. >10 mg of the sample was weighed and placed in the attenuation cell. Before each measurement, it was thoroughly cleaned with anhydrous ethanol. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected on Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD. A monochromatic Al target X-ray source was used, operating at 15 kV and 3 mA. High-resolution spectra were fitted using XPSPeak41 software. The C1s binding energy of 284.8 eV was used for calibration. C2H2-TPD and HCl-TPD were performed on a Tianjin XQ TP-5076 chemisorption instrument. It was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 0.17 g of catalyst was purged in a He gas stream at 100 °C for one hour and was cooled to room temperature. Then, the catalyst was exposed to either acetylene or hydrogen chloride at 170 °C for 4 h. Following adsorption, the sample was purged in a He gas stream for 1 hour. The purge removed any physically adsorbed gas molecules. Finally, the gas adsorbed on the catalyst was desorbed by heating from 30 °C to 850 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was conducted on Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 chemisorber. It was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an OmniStar GSD320 mass spectrometer (MS). 0.1 g of catalyst was purged in the He gas flow (30 mL/min) for 1 hour. Then 5 % H2+95 % Ar (volume fraction) was used as reducing gas at a flow rate of 45 mL/min. The catalyst was reduced by controlled heating. The temperature was increased from room temperature to 850 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was performed on the STA 449C Jupiter thermal analyzer (Netzsch, Germany). Elemental compositions were determined by an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) (Elan DRC-e, PerkinElmer, USA). Before testing, the sample was completely dissolved in aqua regia in a microwave digestion apparatus. The power of this instrument was 1.2 kW. Argon gas served as both the plasma gas and auxiliary gas. Its flow rate was maintained at 1.5 L/min. The pump speed was set to15 rpm. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation Catalyst evaluation experiments are conducted in an atmospheric fixed bed reactor. The acetylene (C₂H₂) feed gas required purification before entering the reactor. The acetylene gas from the steel cylinder was first treated with K2Cr2O7 to remove impurities. It was then bubbled through a concentrated sulfuric acid solution to remove water. The flow rate of the purified C2H2 was then controlled by a mass flow meter. The hydrogen chloride gas of electronic grade purity was used. Therefore, it required no further purification and its flow rate was directly controlled by a separate mass flow meter. A certain amount of catalyst was weighed and diluted with quartz sand to a total volume of 2 mL. Then, it was loaded into quartz reaction tube. The tube had an inner diameter of 10 mm and a length of 550 mm. The empty volume of the quartz tube was filled with quartz sand. After assembling the reactor system, its airtightness was carefully checked. Before the evaluation reaction, the system was purged with nitrogen for 30 min and then was proceeded with programmed heating. After reaching the reaction temperature, the nitrogen flow was stopped. HCl gas was introduced for catalyst activation. This activation period lasted for 30 min. After activation pretreatment, the reaction phase began. The feed gases (C₂H₂ and HCl) were introduced at predetermined flow rates. Product analysis was performed on a Fuli GC9790 chromatograph. It was equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). Detection was based on hydrogen flame ionization. The conversion of acetylene and the selectivity of C2H3Cl were calculated as follows: A c e t y l e n e c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( 1 − F A F A 0 ) × 100 % V C M S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = F V C M 1 − F A × 100 % Where: FVCM represented the volume fraction of C2H3Cl in the product mixture gas; FA0 represented the volume fraction of C2H2 in the raw gas; FA represented the volume fraction of remaining C2H2. 2.4 Theoretical calculation In this work, all calculations were performed by the spin unrestricted DFT method as implemented in DMol[3] code of the Materials Studio package. The electron exchange and correlation effect were described by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) based on the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE). The double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set was adopted. A smearing value of 0.005 Ha was applied to the orbital occupation. This parameter was consistent across all calculations. The convergence tolerance for energy change, max force, and max displacement were 2.0 × 10−5 Ha, 0.004 Ha Å −1, and 0.005 Å, respectively. A 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid was employed to execute the Brillouin-zone integrations. The molecule adsorption energy on the catalyst was defined as: (1) E a d s = E * m o l e c u l e − E * − E m o l e c u l e where E*molecule, E *, and Emolecule represented the energies of catalyst adsorbed with molecule, isolated catalyst, and molecule, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The metal loading is a crucial factor influencing the activity and stability of supported catalysts. To determine the optimal copper content for the Cu/AC system, catalysts prepared with different Cu loadings were initially evaluated. The screening experiments identified 10 wt. % as the most suitable loading (details provided in Fig S1 and accompanying discussion). Subsequently, each reaction parameter to was screened to determine the optimal reaction conditions. Reaction temperature significantly impacts catalyst performance, so this parameter was optimized first. The catalyst (10Cu-[Hnmpo] H2PO4/AC-2) with a molar ratio of n (Cu): n (N)=2:1 was tested. Figure 1(a) shows the temperature-dependent performance. When the reaction temperature increased from 110 °C to 150 °C, the acetylene conversion increased from 35.21 % to 89.16 %. This represents a substantial improvement in catalytic activity. Further temperature increases from 150 °C to 210 °C produced only marginal improvements. In this higher temperature range, conversion increased slightly from 89.16 % to 92.38 %. Therefore, the optimal reaction temperature was determined to be 150 °C. Hourly space velocity (GHSV) was the second key parameter examined. Fig. 1 (b) showed the catalytic performance of 10Cu - [Hnmpo] H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction at different GHSV. When the GHSV of C2H2 increased from 50 h-1 to 150 h-1, the acetylene conversion decreased from 89.16 % to 77.51 %. A Further increase in the GHSV (C2H2) to 1350 h-1 reduced the conversion to 25.27 %. The significant decrease in acetylene conversion was due to the shorter residence time at higher GHSV. This shorter time led to insufficient contact between the substrate molecules and the copper active center. Therefore, the optimal reaction GHSV was 50 h-1. Next, under the optimal reaction conditions, the catalytic performance of catalysts with different molar ratios of n (Cu): n (N) was evaluated. Fig. 2(a) shows the performance results across different Cu:N ratios. The catalyst with n (Cu): n (N) = 2:1 (10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2) demonstrated optimal catalytic performance. This formulation achieved acetylene conversion of 89 %. At this optimal ratio, the corresponding ionic liquid (IL) nominal loading was approximately 16 %. The second most active was n (Cu): n (N)=3:1, with the highest activity of 84.5 %. Next was n (Cu): n (N)=1:1, with the highest acetylene conversion of 79.5 %. Further increases in increase n (Cu): n (N) (i.e., increase in the relative amount of ionic liquid) significantly reduced catalytic activity. Catalysts with higher IL loadings showed maximum acetylene conversion below 60 %. Notably, these heavily loaded catalysts performed worse than the reference 10Cu/AC catalyst tested under identical conditions. This activity reduction can be explained by a physical blocking mechanism. Excessive ionic liquid likely obstructed the pores of the support material. This obstruction increased diffusion limitations and created mass transfer barriers. Consequently, gaseous reactant molecules faced greater difficulty accessing the active centers within the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2 (b), the selectivity of all catalysts for vinyl chloride was greater than 99 %. All catalysts have relatively stable conversion and selectivity during the reaction. This consistent performance confirmed the good stability of the catalyst. To assess the operational durability of the optimized 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst, a long-term stability test was conducted under continuous flow conditions for 70 h under the established optimal reaction conditions (T = 150 °C, GHSV(C2H2) =50 h⁻¹, V(HCl)/V(C2H2) =1.0). The catalytic performance over time is presented in Fig. 3 . As shown in Fig. 3a, the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst demonstrated excellent initial performance. It reached an initial peak acetylene conversion of approximately 89.1 % within the first 10 h. Subsequently, the catalyst maintained a high level of activity over the extended testing period. A very gradual and slight decrease in conversion was observed over the full duration. However, the final conversion at the 70-hour mark remained high at approximately 82.7 %. Overall, this trend indicates remarkable robustness for the catalyst. Critically, selectivity towards the desired product, vinyl chloride (VCM), remained consistently above 99 % throughout the test (Fig. 3b). This sustained high activity and selectivity demonstrate the favorable long-term stability of the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst. Its performance over the extended operational timeframe highlights its potential for prolonged use in acetylene hydrochlorination. 3.2 Characterizations The XRD patterns of the activated carbon support, 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 before and after reaction were shown in Fig. 4 . The pure activated carbon support exhibited two broad diffraction peaks. These peaks appeared at 2θ of approximately 23.3°and 43.6° They correspond to the (002) and (101) crystal planes of graphite carbon, respectively. These are the unique X-ray diffraction peaks of this type of carbon support. Both the fresh and used 10Cu/AC samples showed characteristic diffraction peaks indexed to Cu₂(OH)₃Cl (Paratacamite, PDF #78–0372). These peaks appeared at 2θ values of 16.15°, 32.18°, and 39.76°. They can be attributed to the (011), (013), and (220) crystal planes of Cu₂Cl(OH)₃, respectively. The formation of Cu₂Cl(OH)₃ crystals likely resulted from interactions with atmospheric moisture. This could have occurred during catalyst preparation, reaction, or characterization processes[64]. However, the peak intensity in the fresh 10Cu/AC was very weak. This indicated minimal agglomeration during the preparation stage of the 10Cu/AC catalyst. However, the used 10Cu/AC sample showed much stronger peak intensities at these characteristic positions. This indicates that substantial agglomeration occurred during the reaction. The agglomeration led to the formation of larger Cu₂(OH)₃Cl crystallites. The XRD patterns of 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 before and after reaction showed the same characteristics. These samples displayed only the broad peaks typical of the carbon support. No other characteristic diffraction peaks were observed. This absence of copper-related diffraction peaks suggests two possibilities. Either the Cu active centers were highly dispersed throughout the support, or the Cu content was below the detection limit of the XRD technique. These XRD results confirm the beneficial role of the [Hnmpo]H₂PO₄ ionic liquid. The ionic liquid enhanced the dispersion of Cu active centers on the support and stabilize Cu species. This stabilization helped prevent interference from external environmental atmospheres or moisture. The effect of IL on the anti-carbon-deposition performance of Cu-based catalysts was investigated through low-temperature N2 adsorption-desorption experiments. The results were exhibited in Fig. 4 and Table 1 . According to Fig. 5 , all catalysts displayed Type I nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. This isotherm shape typically indicated predominantly microporous materials. The pore size distribution was notably narrow, ranging between 2–10 nm. The fresh 10Cu/AC catalyst showed excellent textural properties before reaction. It possessed a large specific surface area of 800 m²/g and a total pore volume of 0.38 cm³/g. After the reaction, the specific surface area of 10Cu/AC decreased significantly. Its specific surface area dropped to only 428 m2/g. Similarly, the total pore volume diminished to only 0.19 cm3/g. The BET specific surface area decreased by 46.5 % before and after the reaction, and the total pore volume decreased by 50 %. This substantial degradation can be attributed to the carbon deposition. During the reaction, acetylene polymerization likely occurs on the catalyst surface. These carbon deposits led to pore blockage and coverage of the support. It resulted in a decrease in specific surface area and pore volume. The fresh 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst, which incorporated the ionic liquid, showed slightly lower initial textural properties compared with 10Cu/AC. It had an initial specific surface area of 724 m²/g and a total pore volume of 0.36 cm³/g. After reaction, the used 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 catalyst maintained much of its original textural properties. The specific surface area was 689 m2/g, and the total pore volume was 0.33 cm3/g. These changes represented just a 4.8 % reduction in specific surface area and an 8.3 % decrease in total pore volume. The decrease in specific surface area and total pore volume was significantly lower than that of 10Cu/AC. These results align with the thermogravimetric analysis presented in Fig. 8. Both characterization techniques confirmed that the introduction of [Hnmpo]H₂PO₄ ionic liquid significantly enhanced the catalyst's resistance to carbon deposition. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization was performed to investigate the dispersion of Cu active centers on the catalysts. This analysis aimed to provide microscopic insight into the enhanced activity of the IL-modified catalyst compared with 10Cu/AC. The TEM images of fresh 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalysts were shown in Fig. 6 . The TEM image of fresh 10Cu/AC (Fig. 6a) clearly showed the presence of particles ranging in size from tens to hundreds of nanometers. Based on the XRD results (Fig. 4), these particles are likely composed of Cu₂(OH)₃Cl. The fresh 10Cu/AC exhibited significant and sharp diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 16.15°, 32.18°, and 39.76°. These XRD peaks confirmed the aggregation of Cu active centers observed in the TEM image. The formation of these crystals likely stemmed from exposure to atmospheric moisture. This moisture interaction could have occurred during catalyst preparation, reaction, or characterization processes. The TEM image of 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 revealed no discernible copper-containing nanoparticles. No diffraction peaks corresponding to crystalline copper species were observed for 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 as well (Fig. 4). These results strongly indicated that copper species were highly dispersed in the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst. To further investigate the dispersion of Cu species in the IL-modified catalyst, HAADF-STEM and elemental energy spectrum analysis were also conducted on 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2. Fig. 7 (a) showed the HAADF-STEM image of a certain region of 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2. Consistent with the TEM results, no visible Cu nanoparticles were detected. Fig. 7(b) showed the energy spectrum of 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2. The spectral data revealed that Cu content ranked second only to carbon. It verified successful loading of copper onto the AC. The elemental spectra of 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 were shown in Fig. 6 (c-i). The mapping results demonstrated that Cu species are highly dispersed and uniformly distributed across the carbon support. Similarly, the constituent elements of [Hnmpo]H₂PO₄ ionic liquid—namely N, P, and other elements—also showed excellent dispersion throughout the support. This provided further strong evidence that the ionic liquid modification promoted excellent dispersion of Cu active centers. Table 2 showed the ICP results of 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 before and after the reaction. In the conventional 10Cu/AC catalyst, the copper content measured 10.92 % in the fresh sample. After reaction, this value decreased to 6.69 %. For the ionic liquid-modified catalyst (10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2), the fresh sample contained 11.91 % copper. After reaction, the copper content remained at 10.87 %. The 10Cu/AC catalyst lost a substantial 38.74 % of its initial copper during the reaction. Conversely, the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 catalyst lost only 8.73 % of its copper content. Therefore, the [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid inhibited the loss of Cu species during the reaction. The Fourier transform infrared spectra of [Hnmpo]H2PO4 and 10Cu- [Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 were shown in Fig. 8 . Pure [Hnmpo]H2PO4 exhibited a stretching vibration peak of -CH3 at 2975.1 cm-1. In the spectrum of the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 catalyst, a corresponding peak appears at 2899.2 cm⁻¹. This peak was attributed to the methyl group vibration on the N-alkyl side chain of the [Hnmpo]⁺ cation. The presence of this feature confirmed the successful loading of [Hnmpo] H2PO4 on the activated carbon support. On the other hand, the methyl vibration peak in 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 (2899.2 cm⁻¹) showed a significant red shift compared with the pure ionic liquid. This shift suggested an electronic interaction between the [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid and the Cu active center. Such interaction successfully anchored the Cu active center into the immobilized ionic liquid. Furthermore, the FT-IR spectrum of the pure ionic liquid, [Hnmpo]H2PO4 (curve b), displayed characteristic absorption peaks for the H2PO4⁻ anion within the 1100–800 cm⁻¹ range. These peaks included P-O stretching vibrations observed at approximately 992.6 cm⁻¹ and 881.9 cm⁻¹ [65]. Upon loading onto the catalyst (10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2, curve a), the corresponding H2PO4⁻ features shifted to approximately 1101.9 cm⁻¹ and 877.2 cm⁻¹. Significant changes were also evident in the low-wavenumber region (< 800 cm⁻¹). The pure ionic liquid exhibited distinct peaks at 666.3 cm⁻¹ and 485 cm⁻¹ in this region. They were typically attributed to O-P-O bending modes and other skeletal deformations of the H2PO4⁻ anion. In contrast, these low-frequency peaks become ill-defined or disappear in the catalyst spectrum (curve a), with only a weak feature remaining around 713.5 cm⁻¹. These pronounced alterations across both the P-O stretching and bending regions—including peak shifts, changes in shape, and diminished intensity or disappearance—strongly indicated a significant interaction between the H2PO4⁻ anion and the catalyst surface, particularly the Cu species. This interaction likely occurred via coordination of oxygen atoms from the phosphate group to copper centers, forming P-O-Cu linkages. Such coordination would perturb the anion's electronic structure, alter its chemical bond force constants, and consequently modify its vibrational modes. Carbon deposition is an important cause of catalyst deactivation in acetylene hydrogenation. This phenomenon is particularly problematic for Cu-based catalysts. Thermogravimetric analysis was employed to quantify carbon deposition on the catalysts after reaction. The TG and DTG curves of 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 before and after the reaction were shown in Fig. 9 . The weight loss peak before 100 °C was due to the removal of physically adsorbed water. A significant mass loss occurred between 100 °C and 300 °C. This was attributed to the combustion of deposited carbon species. Above 300 °C, more substantial weight loss occurred due to the combustion of ionic liquid and activated carbon. The amount of carbon deposition on the used catalysts can be estimated from the weight loss percentage in the 100–300 °C range in the TGA curves. According to the TG curve of 10 Cu/AC in Fig. 8(a), the calculated carbon deposition reached 16.39 %. In contrast, the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 catalyst (with Cu:N molar ratio of 2:1) exhibited significantly lower carbon deposition of only 7.77 %. This represented a 52.6 % reduction in carbon deposition compared with the unmodified 10Cu/AC. This indicated that the introduction of [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid significantly enhanced the anti-carbon-deposition ability of Cu-based catalysts. Fig. 10 (a) displayed the temperature programmed desorption (TPD) curves of acetylene adsorbed on 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalysts. Both catalysts showed two desorption peaks. The weaker, lower-temperature peak corresponded to C2H2 desorption from Cu (II) sites. Specifically, acetylene desorbed from Cu (II) on 10Cu/AC at 154 °C. For the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2, this desorption occurred at 175 °C. The 21 °C increase in desorption temperature indicated that the introduction of [Hnmpo]H₂PO₄ ionic liquid substantially enhanced the acetylene adsorption on copper sites. Furthermore, both catalysts exhibited a second, stronger desorption peak at higher temperatures. These peaks appeared at 415 °C for 10Cu/AC and 459 °C for 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2. They may arise from the thermal decomposition of acetylene polymer species on the carbon support. Fig. 10(b) presented the TPD profiles for hydrogen chloride adsorption. The desorption temperature of HCl on 10Cu/AC was 218 °C. For the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2, this temperature increased significantly to 262 °C. The introduction of the [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid significantly increased the HCl desorption temperature by 44 °C. This indicated the enhanced adsorption strength for HCl on the modified catalyst. The ionic liquid introduction simultaneously strengthened the adsorption of both acetylene and hydrogen chloride. Notably, the enhancement effect appeared more pronounced for HCl adsorption than for acetylene. This finding aligns with the subsequent calculated adsorption energies (Fig. 13(a)). Fig. 11 showed the H2-TPR curves of fresh 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalysts. These profiles helped assess the stabilizing effect of the ionic liquid on the valence state of the Cu active center. Both catalysts exhibited three reduction peaks. The first reduction peak was attributed to the reduction of Cu²⁺ species. This peak appears at 366 °C for 10Cu/AC and at 389 °C for 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2. The second reduction peak corresponded to Cu⁺ species. For 10Cu/AC, this reduction occurred at 422 °C. For the ionic liquid-modified catalyst, it shifted to 476 °C. The additional reduction peaks were associated with oxygen-containing functional groups on carbon support or ionic liquid. They were found at 678 °C (10Cu/AC) and 620 °C (10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2). The introduction of [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid increased the Cu2+ reduction temperature by 23 °C and the Cu+ reduction temperature by 54 °C compared with 10Cu/AC. The above results indicated that the ionic liquid enhanced the stability of the Cu-based catalyst against reduction. This stabilization effect likely stemmed from electronic interactions between the ionic liquid and Cu. The interaction suppressed copper reduction and helped maintain Cu in a high valence state. The reduction temperature of oxygen-containing functional groups increased by 58 °C on 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 compared with 10Cu/AC. The desorption amount was also greater than that of 10Cu/AC. This was attributed to the oxygen-containing group from both the carbon support and the ionic liquid. The above results indicated that the [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid better stabilized not only Cun+(n = 1 or 2) but also the oxygen-containing functional groups on the catalyst surface. In order to investigate how the [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid affected the electronic properties of Cu active species, XPS analysis was conducted. Fig. 12 showed the XPS spectra of Cu 2p3/2 for fresh and used 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalysts[66]. For the fresh 10Cu/AC (Fig. 12(a)), the spectrum exhibited peaks attributed to CuCl and CuCl2 at binding energies of 932.8 and 935.2 eV, respectively. Additionally, satellite peaks of Cu 2p3/2 appeared at 939.8 eV and 943.9 eV. Meanwhile, the peak areas attributed to CuCl and CuCl2 were integrated using XPSPEAK41 software. The results indicated that nCuCl: nCuCl2 of fresh 10Cu/AC was 19.22 %: 80.78 %. After the reaction (Fig. 12b), the peaks for CuCl and CuCl2 in the used 10Cu/AC catalyst shifted slightly to binding energies of 932.5 eV and 934.3 eV. The corresponding satellite peaks were observed at 937.2 eV and 942.2 eV. Integration of these peaks revealed that the CuCl:CuCl₂ ratio changed to 48.64 %:51.36 % in the used catalyst. This represented a substantial 29.42 % decrease in CuCl₂ content during the reaction process. The fresh 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst (Fig. 12(c)) exhibited CuCl and CuCl2 peaks at 932.6 and 934.5 eV. Associated satellite peaks were located at 940.94 and 944.10 eV. Integration of these peaks showed an initial nCuCl:nCuCl2 ratio of 31.55 %:68.45 % for the fresh 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2. Figure 12(d) depicts the XPS spectrum of 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H₂PO₄/AC-2 after reaction. Peaks assigned to CuCl and CuCl2 appeared at binding energies of 932.6 eV and 934.8 eV, respectively. The corresponding Cu 2p3/2 satellite peaks were located at 939.0 eV and 944.2 eV. Peak integration determined the nCuCl:nCuCl2 ratio in the used sample to be 40.28 %:59.72 %. Before and after the reaction, CuCl2 in 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 only decreased by 8.73 %. In summary, the [Hnmpo]H2PO4 ionic liquid can effectively stabilized Cu species during the reaction. The ionic liquid had an electronic effect on Cu. This effect enhanced the electropositivity of Cu and promoted the reactant activation. These XPS findings align with the observations from FT-IR and H2-TPR. Furthermore, previous screening of ionic liquids indicated that only ionic liquids containing phosphorus anions provided a promoting effect for the Cu/AC catalyst (Figure S2). 10Cu-20[BMIm]H2PO4/AC-2 had the highest activity, corresponding to an acetylene conversion of 75.1 %. Next was 10Cu-20[BMIm] (C4H9O)2PO2/AC-2, with an activity of 73.5 %. The last was 10Cu-20 [BMIm]PF6/AC-2, with a maximum activity of 72 %. Therefore, it was the P containing anion that optimized the electronic structure of Cu. To further elucidate the microscopic interaction mechanism between the phosphate anion and copper species, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the P 2p and O 1 s core levels was conducted (Fig. 13 and Fig. 14 ). The P 2p spectrum of the reference sample, [Hnmpo]H2PO4 supported on activated carbon (Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC), was presented in Fig. 13a. A characteristic peak corresponding to P(V) in the H2PO4⁻ anion was observed, centered at a binding energy (BE) of 133.6 eV[67]. Upon incorporation into the copper catalyst (10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2, Fig. 13b), this P 2p peak shifted to 134.1 eV. This distinct shift provided direct evidence of electronic interactions resulting from coordination between the H2PO4⁻ anion and the copper species. It altered the chemical environment around the phosphorus atom. The O 1 s XPS spectra offered further insights into the coordination mode (Fig. 14). The O 1 s spectrum of the [Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC reference sample was presented in Fig. 14a. Peak fitting identified components characteristic of the H2PO4⁻ anion. Specifically, peaks were centered at 531.5 eV and 532.8 eV. These features potentially represented P = O and P-O(H)/P-O⁻ environments, respectively[68]. Significant changes were observed for the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst (Fig. 14b). The main peaks associated with phosphate oxygen shifted to approximately 532.0 eV and 533.5 eV. Notably, a new peak emerged at a higher binding energy of 534.6 eV in the catalyst sample. It was attributed to oxygen atoms directly involved in coordination with copper centers (P-O-Cu) [69]. The XPS results provide strong collective evidence for the proposed coordination. Positive shifts were observed in both the P 2p core level and the main O 1 s core levels associated with phosphate oxygen. Furthermore, a new O 1 s peak emerged at a high binding energy of 534.6 eV. These findings strongly supported the conclusion that the H2PO4⁻ anion coordinated to Cu species primarily through an oxygen atom, forming P-O-Cu linkages. Mechanistically, this coordination involved the donation of lone pair electrons from a phosphate oxygen atom to the vacant orbitals of Cu(II) centers, establishing a stable coordinate bond. The formation of this P-O-Cu coordination environment directly modified the d-orbital energy levels of Cu(II). This perturbation enhanced the stability of the Cu(II) electronic configuration, likely increasing its reduction potential. Although coordination occurred via oxygen, the central phosphorus atom within the H2PO4⁻ anion played a crucial role. It dictated the anion's geometry, influenced the charge distribution across the P-O bonds, and modulated the Lewis basicity of the oxygen atoms. The polarity and strength of these P-O bonds ultimately affected the oxygen's ability to donate its lone pair electrons effectively to the copper center, thereby influencing the strength and nature of the crucial P-O-Cu interaction. 3.3 Theoretical calculation Fig. 15 showed the electron cloud density distribution of 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 after adsorbing acetylene and hydrogen chloride, respectively. These calculations were performed using the structural optimization module of ADF software. Figs. 15(a) and (b) showed the electron cloud density maps of 10Cu/AC adsorbing acetylene and hydrogen chloride molecules, respectively. For C₂H₂ adsorption on CuCl₂ (Fig. 15a), the Cu center accepted π-electrons from the CC triple bond. This interaction elongated the CC bond from 1.21 Å to 1.23 Å. Similarly, upon HCl adsorption (Fig. 15b), the CuCl₂ complex activated the HCl molecule. Electron density shifted from the H atom towards a coordinating Cl atom on the Cu center. Consequently, the HCl bond lengthened from 1.29 Å to 1.31 Å. Fig. 12(c) and (d) showed the electron cloud density maps for adsorption on the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 model. On this model (Fig. 15c), C₂H₂ adsorption resulted in a smaller CC bond elongation. The CC bond length increased from 1.205 Å to 1.209 Å. In contrast, HCl adsorption on this model (Fig. 15d) leaded to a greater HCl bond elongation. The HCl bond length increased from 1.30 Å to 1.32 Å. These bond length changes indicated that the [Hnmpo]H₂PO₄ ionic liquid weakened the catalyst's ability to activate C₂H₂ compared with the 10Cu/AC. Conversely, the modified catalyst demonstrated stronger activation of HCl molecules. To further understand how the ionic liquid enhanced catalyst performance, key electronic and energetic factors were investigated. Hirshfeld charge variations of Cu atoms before and after adsorption were examined. Adsorption energies (Eads) for acetylene (C₂H₂) and hydrogen chloride (HCl) were calculated. Fig. 17(a) and (b) showed the adsorption energy of acetylene and hydrogen chloride on 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2, respectively. For the 10Cu/AC model (Fig. 16 (a)), the adsorption energies of acetylene and hydrogen chloride were −53.80 kJ/mol and −28.84 kJ/mol, respectively (Fig. 17 (a)). This indicated that CuCl2 was more likely to adsorb acetylene than hydrogen chloride. The energy released from the adsorption of acetylene and hydrogen chloride by 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 was −179.16 kJ/mol and −195.06 kJ/mol, respectively (Fig. 17(b)). These values represented substantial increases in adsorption strength. The increases were approximately 233 % for C₂H₂ and 576 % for HCl, compared with Eads(10Cu/ACC2H2) and Eads(10Cu/ACHCl). 10Cu/AC. Notably, on the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst, the adsorption of HCl (−195.06 kJ/mol) was energetically more favorable than that of C₂H₂ (−179.16 kJ/mol). This result reversed the trend observed on 10Cu/AC. This indicated that the ionic liquid enhanced significantly strengthens the adsorption of both reactants (C₂H₂ and HCl) on CuCl2. This enhanced adsorption likely contributed to the observed improvement in catalytic performance. In addition, Fig. 18 showed the Hirshfeld charge changes of Cu before and after the adsorption of acetylene and hydrogen chloride. Before adsorption, the Hirshfeld charges of 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 were 0.329 and 0.347, respectively. This result indicated that the ionic liquid altered the electronic structure of the Cu active center. Such modification suggested an enhanced ability to accept acetylene or hydrogen chloride molecule. This electronic modification likely contributed to the improved performance of Cu-based catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. Upon C₂H₂ adsorption, the Hirshfeld charges of Cu atoms in 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 increased to 0.347 and 0.366, respectively. Similarly, upon HCl adsorption, the Cu charges became 0.339 and 0.361 for the 10Cu/AC and 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 models, respectively. Notably, the Hirshfeld charge on Cu in 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 was higher than in the 10Cu/AC, both before and after adsorption of acetylene or hydrogen chloride. This indicated that the [Hnmpo]H2PO4 IL did improve the electronic structure of CuCl2. For both catalysts, acetylene adsorption produced higher Cu Hirshfeld charges than hydrogen chloride adsorption. This also indicated that both catalysts interacted more strongly electronically with the π-system of acetylene than with hydrogen chloride. 3.4 Economic and sustainability aspects The economic viability and environmental sustainability of catalysts are critical factors for industrial application. The 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC catalyst developed in this study demonstrates potential in both areas. From an economic perspective, the catalyst utilized copper as the active species, which was significantly less expensive than precious metals. While the ionic liquid (IL) [Hnmpo]H2PO4 introduced additional cost, its application in a supported form allowed for a controlled amount. Optimal performance was achieved with a relatively moderate nominal IL loading of approx. 16 % (n(Cu):n(N)=2:1. Additionally, the catalyst was prepared using a simple impregnation method. This avoided the complex or costly synthesis procedures potentially required for other catalyst systems. Crucially, incorporating the IL significantly enhanced the catalyst's stability. Carbon deposition on Cu-IL/AC-2 was markedly reduced by 52.6 % compared with Cu/AC (TG results). Furthermore, the loss of the active Cu (II) species decreased dramatically from 38.74 % for Cu/AC to just 8.73 % for Cu-IL/AC-2 (XPS results). This outstanding stability translated to a longer catalyst lifespan and reduced replacement frequency. Consequently, it offered the potential for lower operational costs throughout the catalyst's lifecycle. This enhanced its economic competitiveness against rapidly deactivated Cu/AC and costly precious metal catalysts with limited stability. Regarding sustainability, this catalyst system was designed to replace highly toxic mercury-based catalysts. TGA results (Fig. 9) indicated good thermal stability of the employed IL under the reaction temperature of 150 °C, with major decomposition occurring at higher temperatures (>300 °C). Although potential IL decomposition pathways (e.g., pyrrolidinium ring opening or side-chain cleavage, phosphate group transformations[70]) might occur at elevated temperatures or during extended use, the inherent low volatility of ILs is a key advantage. This property, combined with the IL being immobilized on the support, significantly limited the release of the IL itself or any potential decomposition products into the environment. Furthermore, as confirmed by thermal analysis (Fig. 9), the ionic liquid exhibited good thermal stability and did not undergo significant decomposition at the reaction temperature of 150 °C used in this study. Therefore, while further investigation into the specific environmental impact of long-term IL degradation products is warranted, this system already presents a preferable environmental profile compared with the known high toxicity of mercury or the resource-intensive extraction of precious metals. This is particularly true considering the relatively low toxicity of copper. Moreover, the designability of ILs offers future opportunities to develop even greener and more efficient additives. In summary, the 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC catalyst not only improved the performance of Cu-based catalysts but also offered advantages in terms of lifecycle economics and environmental sustainability. This work provided a valuable reference for developing efficient, cost-effective, and environmentally friendlier non-mercury catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. 4 Conclusions A 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination was prepared with a simple impregnation method. Compared with 10Cu/AC, this catalyst exhibited significantly improved activity and stability. Under the reaction conditions of T = 150 °C, GHSV(C2H2)=50 h-1, and HCl/C2H2=1.0, the acetylene conversion of 89.16 % and the vinyl chloride selectivity of over 99 % were achieved. The modulation of Cu electronic properties by the ionic liquid was the main reason. The ionic liquid enhanced the stability of Cu. This made Cu less prone to agglomeration. Furthermore, it increased the catalyst’s resistance to carbon deposition. The ionic liquid affected the electronic properties of Cu through the coordination of H2PO4 - anion with Cu. Consequently, the active Cu(II) valence state was effectively stabilized. Therefore, the ability of Cu to activate acetylene and HCl was enhanced. Thus, 10Cu-[Hnmpo]H2PO4/AC-2 was a high-performance non-precious metal catalyst. This work provided a useful reference for the development of non-precious metal catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. The promising results suggested potential for future industrial application. coredata.dc:description: The Cu-based catalyst is a highly promising non-precious metal catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. Its activity and stability need to be improved. A specific ionic liquid, [Hnmpo]H2PO4, was developed to modulate the activated carbon-supported Cu (Cu/AC), and a supported ionic liquid-metal catalyst (Cu-[Hnmpo] H2PO4/AC) was prepared. With a n (Cu): n (N) molar ratio of 2:1, the catalyst achieved 89.16 % acetylene conversion and >99 % vinyl chloride selectivity under near-industrial conditions (150 °C, GHSV(C2H2)=50 h⁻¹, HCl/C2H2=1.0). Characterizations and theoretical calculations revealed that ionic liquids increased the stability and anti-carbon-deposition ability of Cu. Ionic liquids modulate the electronic properties of Cu through H2PO4 - anion. The active species in Cu (II) valence state were stably maintained, thereby promoting the activation of acetylene and HCl.
